trial_identification.studytitle: Concordance of an Infrared non-contact thermometer via the temporal area with a digital thermometer via the axilla method in preterm and term infants on admission to the Townsville Neonatal Unit.
trial_identification.scientifictitle: Concordance of an Infrared non-contact thermometer via the temporal area with a digital thermometer via the axilla method in preterm and term infants on admission to the Townsville Neonatal Unit.

conditioncode.conditioncode2: Research that is not of generic health relevance and not applicable to specific health categories listed above

interventions.interventions: Each infant will have his/her temperature taken, first using the digital thermometer under the axilla and then by the infra-red non-contact thermometer via the forehead area. Only one temperature will be taken and this will be on admission to the neonatal unit.
interventions.comparator: The use conventional thermometer under the axilla, which is currently in use on the neonatal unit.

primaryOutcome.outcome: Does the use of the non-contact thermometer agree with the conventional digital thermometer when measuring temperature in the preterm and term infant.
primaryOutcome.timepoint: The infants temperature will be taken on admission to the neonatal unit

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: All infants who are born at The Townsville Hospital and are admitted to the neonatal unit

trial_design.statisticalmethods: Data analysis Numerical data will be described using mean and SD or median in interquartile range (IQR) depending on the distribution. The Bland and Altman (1986) approach for comparing measurement devices will be utilised for individual comparison of each thermometer. In order to detect a mean difference of 0.3C between the axilla and forehead and SD of 0.6, with a power of 80% and 5% level of significance, a sample size of 90 was calculated for each group.

sponsorship.primarysponsoraddress: The Townsville hospital Neonatal unit Angus Smith Drive Douglas Queensland 4814

fundingsource.fundingaddress: Mona Kendall The Townsville Hospital Angus Smith Drive Douglas Townsville Queensland 4814

ethicsAndSummary.summary: The study will compare a non contact infrared thermometer (temple) with a conventional thermometer used on the neonatal unit and evaluate levels of agreement. The use of the non-contact thermometer will ensure minimal disturbance to infants. All Infants admitted to the special care nursery will be able to participate in the study. Temperature recordings will be recoded at each care time. Each infant will be enrolled for the period of time it takes to obtain temple and axilla temperature. We hyponthesize that the non-contact thermometer will be in agreement with the reference thermometer therefore enabling its use in this population.
